{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":3746410,"name":"Jordan Grabanski","username":"little.g.ban","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/little.g.ban/{size}/254880_2.png","created_at":"2025-09-23T23:14:00.972Z","cooked":"

Click Here: FRC Robot Essence Presentation

An FRC robot isn’t a mechanical assembly. It’s not electronics or code.

It’s not drivers, scouters, or strategy.

An FRC robot is in the combination of all those things. They are inseparable. For an example: you can walk in the pits, look at a robot, and have a pretty good idea of how that team was thinking about game strategy just by the design.

As such, I’ve lately found it useful to think in terms of “Robot Essence”.

Robot Essence is Made Up of Four Interrelated Groups:

  1. Game-sense
    Game-sense is the way you imagine the game, and the robots on the field. Game sense is the rules in the manual and the CAN list. It is the tangible feel of the game. That game piece in your hands. Past experience. How robots drive around in space, bounce off one another. Put one way, it’s the collision between physical reality and the rules in your mind.

  2. Strategy
    How do you win a match with your alliance? What strategies are there? What is within your means? What can a third robot do? What can a drive base do? This is a well-trodden path in FRC. In particular, it is very hard to stay off of Karthik’s turf, but I try to take a different angle where I can.

  3. Design
    I am talking about more than just mechanical design here. I emphasize that entering the season with a controllable drivebase and a practiced driver means that you are already a player in this game. Then I briefly introduce what I refer to as the four main FRC mechanisms. Talk about integrating them as black boxes, and then ways to iterate more effectively.

  4. Ideation
    Ideation interacts with every single one of the previous categories—again these are all inseperable from one another. This is about prototypes, rapid robots (alpha-bots). Ways to support your own personal ideation process, and work with ideas as a team. The final section is titled “Where Words End”, trying to hit as close as I can to the nexus of idea generation.

With this presentation, I hope to establish a big picture view of designing a robot to play a game. And, if I’m lucky, capture some things that are known, but difficult to put into language.

SEE THE PRESENTATION NOTES

Inspiration/Sources

PLEASE QUOTE THE ORIGINAL SOURCE

Links Found on the Slide they are Used

…

Karthik, Effective FIRST strategies

Jonathan Norris, “Cycling Optimization”

610 2013 Einstein Cycling

Wildstang 2025 Build Blog, Controls

1678 2016, FRC Dark Secrets

Robonauts “getting away with it”

Marie Curie on the Beauty of Science

Albert Einstein on Imagination

The Beatles, Yellow Submarine Iterations

John Lennon, “All You Need Is Love”

Richard Feynman Interview

George Gershwin Prelude Analysis

“How To Defend A Salad”

321 2024 Einstein Defense

2073 2019 Curie Defense

125, 2017 Feeder

1114 Simbot Sideswipe Intake Day 3 Prototype

1986 2017 Shooter

254 2018 Elevator

254 2025 Alphabot

1241 Week 1 Wooden Robot

971 2023 ARM

254 2019 Robot Image, Sketch

1983 2015 Robot Sketch

973 (RAMP) 2011 Double Joint Robot Concept

Grant Sanderson Reading Interview (3Blue1Brown)

4481 2025 Build Blog Tele-op Cycling Analysis

3100 2025 “The Algae Bot”

2363, 2024 Amp Specialist

John Cage on Silence

2024 Game Reveal Video

Crayon CAD

Will There Be Video?

No clue.

This presentation is new to me, so I want to see if it survives scrutiny. I also want to give it before humans before putting anything online. I will do the trial run with the team in early December.

So: Not anytime soon, likely after the season. If I do, I want to make a series of small videos rather than one long presentation.

Any Relation to "The Fake Book"

Sort of. I’m the same person covering a lot of similar material so there’s a relation to “The Fake Book”. And it is convenient that they are in different forms. But, by and large I personally prefer the way this presentation moves.

Who Am I?

I have been involved with FRC for loosely ~14 years. I got my start in fifth grade following my oldest sibling around—just observing, hunting down tools, being a wrench monkey. I am not a trained engineer, but have mentored team 3926 beginning with the 2024 Crescendo season (favorite game of all time btw)

EDIT: Forget to mention, I am looking for more robot napkin sketches to include in addition to my own. If you have any or can point me towards some I would appreciate it.
